# Choropleth Mapping with R

## 1 Install packages


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(sf, tmap, tidyverse)
```
:::


## 2 Import Data

### 2.1 Importing Geospatial Data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
```

:::


### 2.2 Importing attribute data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata <- read_csv("data/aspatial/respopagesextod2011to2020.csv")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Rows: 984656 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (5): PA, SZ, AG, Sex, TOD
dbl (2): Pop, Time

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
```


:::
:::


## 3 Data Preparation

### 3.1 Data Wrangling


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata2020 <- popdata %>%
  filter(Time == 2020) %>%
  group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>%
  summarise(`POP` = sum(`Pop`)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  pivot_wider(names_from=AG, 
              values_from=POP) %>%
  mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[3:6])
         +rowSums(.[12])) %>%
mutate(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` = rowSums(.[7:11])+
rowSums(.[13:15]))%>%
mutate(`AGED`=rowSums(.[16:21])) %>%
mutate(`TOTAL`=rowSums(.[3:21])) %>%  
mutate(`DEPENDENCY` = (`YOUNG` + `AGED`)
/`ECONOMY ACTIVE`) %>%
  select(`PA`, `SZ`, `YOUNG`, 
       `ECONOMY ACTIVE`, `AGED`, 
       `TOTAL`, `DEPENDENCY`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'PA', 'SZ'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
```


:::
:::


### 3.2 Joining the attribute data and geospatial data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata2020 <- popdata2020 %>%
  mutate_at(.vars = vars(PA, SZ), 
          .funs = list(toupper)) %>%
  filter(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` > 0)
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz_pop2020 <- left_join(mpsz, popdata2020,
                          by = c("SUBZONE_N" = "SZ"))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
write_rds(mpsz_pop2020, "data/mpszpop2020.rds")
```
:::


## 4 Plotting a choropleth map


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tmap_mode("plot")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
tmap mode set to plotting
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qtm(mpsz_pop2020, 
    fill = "DEPENDENCY")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.1 Creating a choropleth map using tmap's elements


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY", 
          style = "quantile", 
          palette = "Blues",
          title = "Dependency ratio") +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Distribution of Dependency Ratio by planning subzone",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 1.2,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 0.35,
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar() +
  tm_grid(alpha =0.2) +
  tm_credits("Source: Planning Sub-zone boundary from Urban Redevelopment Authorithy (URA)\n and Population data from Department of Statistics DOS", 
             position = c("left", "bottom"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.2 Drawing a base map


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020) +
  tm_polygons()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.3 Drawing a choropleth map using tm_polygons()


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_polygons("DEPENDENCY")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.4 Add borders and shade


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.5 Add boundary of the planning subzone (according to the respective dependency values)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY") +
  tm_borders(lwd = 0.1,  alpha = 1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.6 Data classification methods using tmap

#### i. jenks


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY",
          n = 5,
          style = "jenks") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### ii. equal


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY",
          n = 5,
          style = "equal") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Each method gives different dependency classifications due to different interpretation of groupings and data distribution from each method. Fixed method requires break points in order to be plotted.

### 4.7 Plotting choropleth map with custome break


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(mpsz_pop2020$DEPENDENCY)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
 0.1111  0.7147  0.7866  0.8585  0.8763 19.0000      92 
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY",
          breaks = c(0, 0.60, 0.70, 0.80, 0.90, 1.00)) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Values have found that are higher than the highest break
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex08_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### 4.8 Colour Scheme
